'''[[Guardian (Newspaper) (Earth-616)|Guardian]] newspapers''' | FormerMembers = Unnamed conspiring board,{{r|Wolverine and the X-Men #19}} Mr. Childs, [[Maximus Lobo (Earth-616)|Maximus Lobo]] and '''[[Lobo Technologies (Earth-616)|Lobo Technologies]]''', [[Candace Southern (Earth-616)|Candy Southern]], [[Character Index/E#Edmund|Edmund]] ([[Guardian (Newspaper) (Earth-616)|Guardian]] editor) | Identity = Public | Affiliation = | Allies = [[Matthew Murdock (Earth-616)|Matthew Murdock]] (attorney), [[X-Men (Earth-616)|X-Men]], [[X Foundation (Earth-616)|X Foundation]], formerly [[Kade Kilgore (Earth-616)|Kilgore]]'s [[Hellfire Club (Earth-616)|Hellfire Club]] (conspiring board){{r|Wolverine and the X-Men #5}} | Enemies = [[Kade Kilgore (Earth-616)|Kilgore]]'s [[Hellfire Club (Earth-616)|Hellfire Club]] | Origin = | Reality = Earth-616 | Status = Active | BaseOfOperations = Worthington tower, [[Manhattan]]; [[San Francisco]]; [[Philadelphia (Pennsylvania)|Philadelphia]]{{r|X-Factor #10}}
Formerly [[White Plains]] {{r|Uncanny X-Men Vol 1 418}} ([[Lobo Technologies]]) | PlaceOfFormation = | PlaceOfDissolution = | Creators = | First = | History = ===Origin and Overview=== The Worthington Industries was founded over 150 years ago, by the Worthington family,{{r|X-Factor #57}} and today has become an international conglomerate with holdings in advanced aviation technology, periodicals (at least one newspaper), experimental alternative fuels and fancy frozen yoghurts, with nearly uncountable net worth.{{r|Wolverine & the X-Men #5}} ===Support of the Mutant Cause=== The last few years, the company's CEO was [[Warren Worthington III (Earth-616)|Warren Worthington III]], who used the resources of the company to sponsor the [[X-Men (Earth-616)|X-Men]]. ===Angel Amnesiac=== Due to his amnesia, the board of directors removed Warren from leadership,{{r|Wolverine and the X-Men #5}} as they were conspiring against Worthington in order to illegally take control of the company.{{r|Wolverine and the X-Men #19}} The whole board was oriented by [[Kade Kilgore (Earth-616)|Kilgore]]'s [[Hellfire Club (Earth-616)|Hellfire Club]] who offered them a private island.{{r|Wolverine and the X-Men #5}} Helped with the attorney [[Matthew Murdock (Earth-616)|Matthew Murdock]], he regained control of his company, firing all the board members as their conspiration was telepathically proved. In order to replace them and as Angel didn't wanted to run his company but rather help new mutants, he recruited for his new board [[Victor Borkowski (Earth-616)|Anole]], [[Ruth Aldine (Earth-616)|Blindfold]], [[Roxanne Washington (Earth-616)|Bling!]] and [[Hisako Ichiki (Earth-616)|Armor]], his pals from A.P. Economics Class, the "best available candidates". Daredevil then left, pretty worried for Worthington Industries' health in the hands of the younglings, while Anole was intending to buy [[Wikipedia:Disney|Disney]].{{r|Wolverine and the X-Men #19}} | Equipment = | Transportation = | Weapons = | Notes = * The company was apparently founded by the [[Warren Worthington (Earth-616)|Warren Worthington I]]'s parents or grandparents. * [[Lobo Technologies]] is a subsidiary of Worthington Industries, owned by [[Maximus Lobo (Earth-616)|Maximus Lobo]], headquartered in [[White Plains]], [[New York]].{{r|Uncanny X-Men #417|420}} * The [[Guardian (Newspaper) (Earth-616)|Guardian]] is a newspaper owned by a filial subsidiary of Worthington Industries. | Trivia = | Links = }} [[Category:Companies]]
